Novel ammonia synthesis catalysts are sought due to energetic transformation and increasing environmental consciousness. Materials containing cobalt and molybdenum are showing state-of-art activities in ammonia synthesis. The application of γ-alumina support was proposed to enhance the properties of Co-Mo nanoparticles. The wet impregnation of the support was conducted under reduced pressure. The active catalysts were obtained by ammonolysis of precursors. The chemical and phase composition, as well as morphology, porosity, and surface composition of precursors and catalysts, were characterized. The Co-Mo nanoparticles phase composition as well as their size and dispersion were determined using X-ray absorption spectroscopy utilizing synchrotron radiation, electron microscopy, and X-ray scattering. The catalytic activity was tested in the ammonia synthesis process under atmospheric pressure. The activity and stability of the supported catalysts were compared with unsupported cobalt molybdenum nitride Co3Mo3N, revealing the superiority of the present approach. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ammonia synthesis Supported catalyst Cobalt molybdenum nitrides Gamma-alumina Stability Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Transition metal nitrides (TMNs) are materials of high importance as their properties combine those of both ceramics (hardness, strength, corrosion resistance) and metals, (electrical conductivity and magnetic properties) [1]. Furthermore, TMNs also exhibit catalytic properties similar to those of platinum group elements, making them potentially suitable for use in industrial chemical synthesis [2]. TMNs are active in the processes of ammonia synthesis [3], hydrotreatment of petroleum raw materials [4], hydrogenation and dehydrogenation of organic compounds [5], and dry reforming of methane [6]. Their use as electrocatalysts in oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is also being investigated [7,8]. The use of TMNs in industrial installations is limited by the high price of raw materials [9]. In recent years, more attention has been paid to such ammonia synthesis catalysts with TMNs as the active phase [10]. This is due to the encouraging results from theoretical calculations, based on nitrogen adsorption energy, which have shown that Co-Mo sites may be one of the most active in ammonia synthesis [11]. The ternary nitrides in the cobalt-molybdenum-nitrogen (CoMoN) system, which include, among others, nitrides with the Co3Mo3N and Co6Mo6N stoichiometry, show greater activity in the Haber-Bosch ammonia synthesis reaction than the iron catalysts commonly used in the industry [12]. Many different preparation methods for cobalt molybdenum nitrides are reported in the literature [13–19]. A commonly used two-stage process consists of the precipitation of an oxide precursor and its subsequent activation in an ammonia atmosphere or a mixture containing ammonia, hydrogen, and nitrogen [13]. An increase in the activity of CoMoN can be achieved by adding electron donor promoters, such as compounds of alkali metals, especially cesium or potassium [14,20]. Also, the increase of the activity of CoMoN in the synthesis of ammonia can be enhanced by activating the surface of a catalyst, by passivation and reduction processes [21]. It has been proved that this is due to the increased number of active sites and an increase in the reactivity of surface nitrogen in the structure of nitrides [22–25]. The surface area of a catalyst consisting of CoMoN can be developed by the addition of a structural promoter in the form of chromium compounds [26–28]. Also, chromium promotion addresses the problem of catalyst deactivation, resulting from the sintering of the active phase crystallites. Still, the method itself can introduce impurities that can affect the catalytic performance negatively. The preparation of supported catalysts is a solution commonly used in the chemical industry, which allows for an increase in the specific surface area [29]. The application of the active phase to the material with a well-developed porous structure allows for a reduction in the price of the catalyst by decreasing the needed amount of valuable elements. This is crucial for materials containing cobalt, because according to the European Commission's policy, the use of cobalt, which is a strategic raw material in lithium-ion batteries, should be restricted [30]. Furthermore, the preparation of supported catalysts increases the stability of the catalyst system, e.g. by inhibiting the sintering of the active phase crystallites, which in turn translates into a longer lifespan of the catalyst. Most published literature regarding supported Co-Mo catalysts focuses on the hydrotreatment processes, more specifically hydrodesulfurization, due to their commercial use in the refining industry [31–35]. In these processes, the active phases of the Co-Mo compounds exist either in the oxide form, sulfide (promoted by cobalt), or as cobalt molybdenum sulfide [36,37]. The use of supported CoMoN as catalysts was reported for the dehydrogenation of organic compounds and the decomposition of ammonia [38–41]. The use of bimetallic Co-Mo nanoparticles supported by ceria in the process of ammonia synthesis was studied recently [42–45]. Material consisting of Co to Mo 4:6 molar ratio on CeO2 exhibited comparable TOF to efficient Ru/CeO2 catalyst [42]. The occurrence of indirectly formed Co3Mo3N nanoparticles was identified by XANES analysis of Co-Mo/CeO2 materials studied after catalytic tests. Thus, the Co3Mo3N nanoparticles obtained on support were proposed to be an alternative to Ru catalysts. More recently, direct methods for the synthesis of supported CoMoN, with enhanced ammonia synthesis activity and high specific surface area, have been proposed [46,47]. In the work of Sfeir et al., the precursor is obtained by utilization of a multi-step (hydrothermal and impregnation-infiltration) preparation method [46]. After mesoporous SBA-15 (silica-based sieve) preparation, incipient wetness impregnation method, and calcination are conducted to obtain MoO3 supported on SBA-15. Then Co is introduced by the melt infiltration method. A precursor is then calcinated at 500 °C, subjected to ammonolysis at 785 °C and passivated. In that way, catalysts with relatively high 10–30 wt% loadings were obtained. Rai et al. reported Co3Mo3N supported on various MgO supports [47]. Catalyst obtained on single-crystalline MgO exhibited activity of 162 mmol·gmetal −1·h−1 which is 10 times more in comparison to reference Co3Mo3N studied in the same conditions (15 mmol·gmetal −1·h−1). Activity enhancement was ascribed as a result of active phase-support interplay and an increased number of basic sites on support. The synthesis method presented in our work allows to receive materials, which exhibit superior activity related to active metal mass in the synthesis of ammonia measured at atmospheric pressure and show greater resistance to overheating than the reference unsupported CoMoN catalysts. The proposed synthesis method utilizes impregnation under reduced pressure, which enables the impregnation solution to be introduced into the pores of the carrier and obtains a homogeneous product with a high degree of dispersion. The structural identity of the active phase nanoparticles was proposed based on the synchrotron studies and quasi-in situ surface analysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Commercial γ-alumina (catalyst support, high surface area, ThermoFisher Scientific, Germany), was used as a carrier. It was crushed in a mortar and its fraction 1.0–1.2 mm was collected. The alumina was dried before synthesizing the catalysts. The catalyst precursors were obtained by impregnating alumina with aqueous solution (deionized water): cobalt(II) nitrate(V) hexahydrate (analytical grade, Chempur, Poland) and ammonium molybdate(VI) tetrahydrate (analytical grade, Chempur, Poland). Solutions with a concentration of 0.2 M and a volume such as to obtain catalysts with a designed content of metallic cobalt and molybdenum ranging from 3 to 9 % by weight were used at a constant mole ratio of cobalt to molybdenum nCo/nMo = 1. The impregnation was carried out at a pressure of 200 mbar and a temperature of 60 °C until the water was completely removed. After impregnation, the materials were dried at 100 °C overnight. The precursors were then activated by ammonolysis in pure ammonia (UHP, Messer Poland) at 700 °C for 2 h. In the temperature program, the heating to the temperature of 650 °C was applied at the rate of 5 °C/min, and then the heating to the temperature of 700 °C at the rate of 1 °C/min. The materials were then cooled to room temperature under ammonia flow and flushed with nitrogen (5.0, Messer Poland). Reference material in the form of a carrier-free catalyst was also prepared, consisting of cobalt molybdenum nitrides, obtained analogously to the supported catalysts only without the addition of the support. 2.2 Catalysts characterization methods Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis was performed on the Hitachi SU8020 device. Micrographs of the surface topography of the analyzed materials were taken with the use of a secondary electrons (SE) detector at a voltage of 5 kV and an intensity of 5 μA. In turn, elemental mapping images with the EDX (Energy-dispersive X-ray) spectra were taken using a voltage of 20 kV and an intensity of 10 μA. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) imaging was conducted utilizing the FEI Tecnai F20 microscope, operating at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The samples were evenly dispersed on the copper grid with lacey carbon film. The images were captured across a minimum of 10 distinct areas, to ensure a statistically representative sampling of the entire material. Textural properties of catalyst precursors and catalysts in active form were determined using nitrogen adsorption/desorption at −196 °C (volumetric method). The analysis was performed on the Autosorb Instrument by Quantachrome. The specific surface area (SBET) was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and total pore volume (Vp) was determined for relative pressure 0.99. Before the actual analysis, the tested materials were degassed under vacuum at the temperature of 200 °C for 16 h. The nitrogen used for the tests was of 5.0 purity. A Philips Panalytical X'pert MPD diffractometer with a cobalt anode lamp was used for the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) tests. For the analysis of diffraction data, the PANalytical HighScore Plus program with access to the ICDD PDF4+ database was used. The experimental procedure used in the case of XRPD consisted of grinding the materials in an agate mortar and collecting the diffraction patterns in the range of 10–120 °2θ with a step of 0.026 °2θ. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy ICP-OES was used to study the chemical composition. The samples were prepared by digestion in a PerkinElmer Titan MPS 8 microwave mineralizer at 180 °C for 30 min. Hydrochloric acid (Chempur, ultrapure) was used for digestion. The PerkinElmer Avio 500 spectrometer was used to determine the cobalt, molybdenum, and aluminum content in the samples. The X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements were conducted at the ASTRA beamline of the SOLARIS Synchrotron in Kraków, Poland. Spectra at the Mo L3- and Co K-absorption edges were measured using a photon beam delivered by a state-of-the-art double-bend achromatic 1.3 T bending magnet with a critical energy of approximately 2 keV. The beam was monochromatized using a Ge(220) crystal pair for the Co K-absorption edge measurements and an InSb(111) crystal pair for the Mo L3-absorption edge measurements, with a beam size of 7 × 1 mm at the sample position. Spectra were obtained in transmission mode with ionization chambers and the sample chamber filled with N2 gas at atmospheric pressure for Co K-edge measurements and pressure of 25 torr for Mo L3-edge measurements. Co foil from Exafs Company was used as a reference for measurements at the Co K-edge, while calibration at the Mo L3-edge was performed using ZnSO4∙7H2O, known for its intense whiteline at 2481.4 eV. For Co K-edge measurements, samples were prepared as pellets with a cellulose matrix. For Mo L3-edge measurements, the powders were meticulously ground with a mortar and pestle, then spread evenly on Kapton tape, pre-verified to be free from S, Cl, and Mo signals. The study was focused on two primary samples: the CoMoO(9)/Al2O3 precursor and the CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 activated catalyst, alongside six reference samples: Co metal foil, unsupported CoMoO4·nH2O, Co3Mo3 N, CoO, Co3O4, and Mo2N. The Demeter software package was used for advanced data processing and analysis, ensuring precise and accurate results. The surface of the sample containing 9 wt% was examined using the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Mg Kα (hν = 1253.6 eV) radiation source was used. The instrument used was the multi-chamber UHV system (Prevac, Poland) operating in the pressure range below 1·10−8 mbar equipped with SES 2002 (Scienta, Sweden) electron energy detector operating at a constant pass energy of 50 eV. Charging effects were corrected based on one-point calibration assuming the binding energy of the CH component of C 1 s region as 285.0 eV. The results were processed using Casa XPS software. Each sample was dried (200 °C) and degassed before examination. The granules of the precursor were analyzed on a silver-plated carrier. The other sample, after undergoing activation through ammonolysis at 700 °C and passivation in the air, was pulverized and formed into a tablet. It was inserted into the UHV system on a carrier designed for high-temperature reactions. One of the chambers of the UHV system is equipped with a high-pressure cell (HPC). It enables conducting high-temperature treatments under a flow of reactive gasses, followed by evacuation of the cell and rapid transfer of a treated sample to the analysis chamber without exposure to air. The activated catalyst sample was subjected to such a treatment under an H2:N2 atmosphere of a 3:1 vol ratio (both 5.0 purity, Messer Poland, total flow of 40 cm3/min) at the temperature of 550 °C for 5 h in the HPC. Then the HPC was evacuated and the sample was transferred for analysis under UHV conditions. Linseis STA PT1600 thermobalance was used for thermogravimetric (TG) measurements. Measurements were conducted with varied temperature and gas flow regulated with a set of mass flow controllers. A platinum sample holder was used. The weight measurement resolution was 0.5 μg with a sample mass of about 0.1 g. Small-angle X-ray Scattering (SAXS) measurements were conducted using the MOUSE instrument (Bundesanstalt für Materialforschung und –prüfung (BAM), Berlin, Germany) [48]. X-rays were generated from microfocus X-ray tubes, followed by multilayer optics to parallelize and monochromatize the X-ray beams to the Cu Kα (λ = 0.154 nm) and Mo Kα (λ = 0.071 nm) wavelengths. Scattered radiation was detected on an in-vacuum Eiger 1 M detector (Dectris, Switzerland), which was placed at multiple distances between 138 and 2507 mm from the sample. The resulting data was subsequently processed and scaled using the DAWN software package in a standardized manner with the propagation of uncertainties [49,50]. The data was then analyzed using the McSAS software package to extract form-free size distributions using Monte Carlo methods [51]. 2.3 Activity and stability tests The rate of ammonia synthesis on the obtained catalysts was determined under atmospheric pressure. The measuring system consisted of a plug-flow, tubular laboratory reactor, an absorber with a solution of sulfuric acid, and a conductometer. A mass of 0.2 g of catalyst was used for measurements. The flow of reaction gases (nitrogen and hydrogen of 5.0 purity) in the reactor was constant and amounted to 45 cm3/min of H2 and 15 cm3/min of N2, respectively. A solution of 0.001 molar sulfuric acid was used. The ammonia synthesis process was carried out at 500 °C. After overheating the catalysts at 700 °C for 2 h under the atmosphere of reaction gases, the activity test described above was repeated. The rate of ammonia synthesis for the 9 wt% load catalyst was measured during a 5-day test in the same reactor as described above. In that case, the concentration of the ammonia in the exhaust stream was measured every 10 s using a Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) gas analyzer Bruker Omega 5, equipped with a 5 m multi-reflection gas cell. The gas analyzer has been calibrated by the manufacturer. 3 Results and discussion The catalysts with 3, 6, and 9 wt% total load of metals (Co+Mo) deposited with wet impregnation on high surface γ-Al2O3 were obtained using a two-step procedure. First, the precursors denoted as CoMoO(wt%)/Al2O3 were acquired through wet impregnation in a laboratory rotating evaporator on the alumina carrier, where the visual inspection was used to assess the effective deposition of cobalt molybdate hydrate (e.g. when white alumina granules changed color to violet, Figure S1a) [52]. In the next step, the precursors were activated by the ammonolysis process (heating at 700 °C in the flow of ammonia) to form nitrides denoted henceforth as CoMoN(wt%)/Al2O3. The color of the material changed to black, suggesting the reduction to its metallic form or nitriding (Figure S1 g). The morphology of precursors as well as activated catalysts, examined by SEM imaging, revealed similarities to that of γ-Al2O3 support. No agglomerates of the precipitated Co/Mo phases were observed on the outer surface of carrier grains (Figure S1b and S1 h). The EDX mapping of Al, Co, and Mo atoms (Figure S1c-e and S1i-k) shows a dominant concentration of Al atoms and a consistent dispersion of the active elements (Co and Mo) throughout the samples. It confirms the homogenous dispersion of the Co-Mo nanoparticles in the volume of the carrier. TEM micrographs were collected in an attempt to determine the dimensions of the deposited particles (Figs. 1a and 1b). Darker spots ascribed to a Co-Mo phase were in both cases in size of around 1–2 nm. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were collected at −196 °C and are presented in Supplementary Materials (Fig. S2). According to the IUPAC technical report, all obtained isotherms indicate isotherm type IVa, which is characteristic of mesoporous materials [53]. The occurrence of the hysteresis proves the presence of pores wider than 4 nm. The calculated specific surface area of the support is 250 m2/g with a total pore volume of 0.80 cm3/g, which is in accordance with the manufacturer's specifications (i.e. 220 to 280 m2/g and 0.80 to 1.20 cm3/g). The analysis confirmed that the obtained catalysts have a high specific surface area close to the pure support (Table 1 ), though it should be noted that a small decrease in the specific surface area is observed after activation. These results correspond well to the SEM images confirming that the nanometric mesopores of the support were not affected by the impregnation of the Co/Mo compounds. The observed slight loss of the specific surface area as well as total pore volume occurs due to the increased load of those compounds. Examination of the chemical composition (ICP-OES) confirmed the presence of cobalt and molybdenum in the bulk of catalysts (Table 2 ). The measured load of cobalt and molybdenum is close to the nominal load of these elements, providing validation for the use of the chosen preparation method. X-ray powder diffractograms of the precursor and activated catalyst are shown in Fig. S3, where only broad reflections matching the reference pattern (PDF 04–007–2615 of γ-Al2O3) are observed. All of the characteristic crystal planes reflections of γ-Al2O3 (111) at 22.6 °2θ, (220) at 37.3 °2θ, (311) at 44.1 °2θ, (222) at 46.1 °2θ, (400) at 53.8 °2θ, (333) at 72.0 °2θ, and (440) at 79.6 °2θ were identified [54]. No reflections corresponding to cobalt molybdates or cobalt molybdenum nitrides phases were identified, even though cobalt and molybdenum atoms are present within the bulk of the catalysts as identified with ICP-OES and SEM-EDX. Hence, with the application of classical laboratory methods, the structure of the active phase cannot be identified. This is likely an effect of the high dispersion and low dimensions of the particles of the deposited cobalt and molybdenum species, as verified by electron microscopy, with an average size below 2 nm. Therefore, the chemical form of the active phase was probed using XAS using synchrotron radiation at the Co K-absorption edge and Mo L3-absorption edge. The XANES spectra CoMoO(9)/Al2O3 precursor and CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 activated catalyst were compared to the reference Co foil, CoMoO4·H2O, Co3Mo3 N, Co3O4 and CoO (Fig. 2a ). XANES spectra of metal Co atoms have pronounced feature in the range 7705 eV - 7717 eV (grey area in Fig. 2a), oxidized cobalt atoms do not have this feature. The unsupported Co3Mo3N exhibited spectra features similar to that of the Co foil, which is in accordance with the crystal structure of Co3Mo3N, consisting of corner-sharing [Mo6N] octahedra net and the corner-sharing supertetrahedra diamondoid net of cobalt atoms [55]. In general, one could see that the shape of the spectra of both CoMoO(9)/Al2O3 and CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 have features corresponding to oxidized cobalt species. The spectrum of the precursor CoMoO(9)/Al2O3 has similar features and close absorption edge position to cobalt molybdate CoMoO4·H2O. The activated catalyst CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 spectra showed a lower intensity of a whiteline than CoMoO(9)/Al2O3 and the presence of a small pre-edge feature. These observations suggest that metallic-like Co species exist within CoMoN(9)/Al2O3. Thus, the active form might consist of both Co and/or Co3Mo3N, since in both states Co species are in a zero valence state [56]. The existence of oxidized species in the active form of catalysts is probably due to incomplete nitriding of the precursor or by oxidation of the Co-Mo nanoparticles in contact with the air. The Fourier transform of EXAFS spectra χ(k)k2 was carried out in the k range from 2.8 Å−1 up to 10 Å−1 (Fig. 2b). The EXAFS analysis of CoMoO(9)/Al2O3 is in accordance with the XANES conclusions, revealing Co-O coordination at 1.5 Å as in CoMoO4·H2O. The Co-Co coordination at 2 Å (grey area in Fig. 2b) is not visible in CoMoO(9)/Al2O3. After activation in sample CoMoN(9)/Al2O3, the peak at 2.7 Å corresponding to Co-O coordination in Co3O4 is identified. The increasing Co3O4 content present in the CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 is in agreement with the in situ studies of the ammonolysis process of CoMoO4·H2O to Co3Mo3N suggesting the initial stage of the ammonolysis process [18]. The linear combination fitting was used to determine the composition of CoMoO(9)/Al2O3 with the highest probability (Fig. S4). Using Co foil, CoMoO4·H2O, Co3Mo3N, and Co3O4 as references in linear fit the result of 91 % of CoMoO4·H2O and 9 % of Co3O4 was received nevertheless of phases included in fitting (Table S1). The composition of the activated material, CoMoN(9)/Al2O3, shows minor differences depending on whether the Co or Co3Mo3 N phase is used as a reference. The CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 is most likely composed of 34 % of CoMoO4·H2O, 58 % of Co3O4, and 8 % Co (Fig. S5). However, by excluding Co from fitting the result of 34 % of CoMoO4·H2O and 60 % of Co3O4 and 6 % Co3Mo3N with only a minor difference in probability, thus the presence of Co3Mo3N cannot be fully excluded. These observations were further confirmed with the XANES Mo L3-edge measurement (Fig. 3 ). The Mo2N and Co3Mo3N spectra look similar due to the presence of Mo in the same environment. XANES spectra of metal Mo atoms have pronounced features in the range 2520.5 eV - 2524 eV (grey area in Fig. 3a and 3b). Both spectra of CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 precursor and CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 activated catalyst are similar to that observed for CoMoO4·H2O. However, while the precursor CoMoO(9)/Al2O3 catalyst XANES 2nd derivative measurements (Mo L3-edge) revealed the clearly visible features (peaks at 2525 and 2527 eV) corresponding to d orbital splitting, in the activated CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 those features are not so pronounced. This difference indicates that in the case of CoMoO(9)/Al2O3, the structure of oxidized Mo is highly ordered and on the other hand in CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 more defected, again indicating the changes in the material which happens during ammonolysis process as observed by in situ studies [18]. What is also worth noting is that the reference Co3Mo3N material exhibited similar features but at a much lower intensity (green arrows in Fig. 3b) indicating that Co3Mo3N was slightly oxidized during contact with air. The observed splitting of the line (Table 3 ) indicates the ligand field splitting of the final state d-orbital [57]. The differences in splitting and relative intensities were explained using ligand field theory. At the Mo L3-edge, the whiteline arises from dipole-allowed 2p → 4d transitions [57]. The occurrence of the two whitelines is attributed to the transition of electrons from 2p3/2 to split 4d states. The number of available orbitals should also be evident in the relative intensity of each transition. For a Mo atom with tetrahedral coordination, the d-orbital splitting is smaller compared to Mo in an octahedral field (e, t2 versus t2 g, eg) [57]. Observed relative intensities follow the relationship of Ie/It2=2/3 for the tetrahedron and It2g/Ieg=3/2 for the octahedron [58,59]. The most intense part of the split peak appears at a higher energy for the tetrahedral MoO4 subunit, while for the octahedral coordination, the most intense component is found at a lower energy [58]. As the intensity of the whiteline on the higher energy side is higher than that on the lower energy side, the concluded predominant local structure of both CoMoO(9)/Al2O3 and CoMoO(9)/Al2O3 is tetrahedral containing (MoO4) subunits [60]. It is also visible that the 2nd peak in both CoMoO(9)/Al2O3 and CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 consists of two features (black arrows at Fig. 3b) indicating additional presence of distorted MoO6 octahedra in material [58,59]. Most of the previously presented results were affected by the problem of exposure of the sample to air after ammonolysis and before analysis. It needs to be avoided to mimic the state of the material during the activity test. Thus, XPS analyses utilizing the quasi-in situ capabilities of the available apparatus were performed to investigate the chemical states of Co and Mo atoms. Two samples with the projected total concentration of Co and Mo of 9 wt% were analyzed. XPS analysis of the precursor granules confirms the presence of oxygen, aluminum, cobalt, molybdenum, and carbon (adventitious [61]) atoms on the surface. The quantitative analysis allowed for the estimation of surface concentrations of both Co and Mo of about 2 at%. This result is of the same magnitude as that obtained from ICP-OES analysis, suggesting that the active elements are saturating the support pores and are not forming a shell-like structure on the outer surface. The activated catalyst was subjected to a reduction process in a synthesis gas mixture (H2:N2) in the HPC (as described in the Experimental section). The process was meant to reduce the layer of oxides formed during exposure to air and thus mimic as closely as technically possible the procedure conducted during the activity measurements. After the reduction, the HPC was evacuated and the catalyst was transferred to the analysis chamber under UHV conditions. Thus, the analysis was performed on the reduced material that was not subsequently in contact with oxygen. An estimation of Co and Mo atoms concentration on the surface was in agreement with the results for the precursor, showing that no migration to or from the surface occurs. Analysis of the high-resolution spectra of both cobalt and molybdenum regions (Fig. 4a and 4b, respectively) allowed for the observation that under both conditions, the active elements are mostly oxidized. Importantly, in the Co 2p region, there is a slight decrease in the intensity of the component ascribed to the oxidized state and the appearance of a small component shifted towards lower binding energies (supposedly Co-N). The reduction is more apparent in the Mo 3d region (Fig. 4b). Both the precursor and activated catalysts show two distinct peaks at 234.7 and 231.6 eV, though the treated sample also has a shoulder at 229.4 eV, corresponding to a Mo-N bond. This observation may indicate that during exposure to the synthesis gas mixture surface reduction of Co-Mo species is happening. Whether the observed reduction applies to a reconstruction of the nitride structure from the passive layer created on the nitrides or just the formation of metallic Co and Mo species remains uncertain. The residual oxidized active elements might be present due to the thickness of the passive layer created and insufficient temperature and/or time of the final reduction. Despite this, it is implied that the material requires a prolonged reactivation step after exposure to air. Also, it was confirmed that no shell of Co/Mo compounds is forming on the surface of the analyzed material and the active phase is evenly distributed in the porous support. The catalytic activity of all obtained catalysts was examined in a laboratory fixed bed reactor under atmospheric pressure at 500 °C. By blind test utilizing Al2O3 pretreated the same way as the rest of the examined catalysts, the possibility that the detected ammonia is a result of the loss of adsorbed ammonia from the ammonolysis process was excluded. The obtained results were presented as the catalytic activity related to the catalyst mass (Table 4 ). With the same procedure, the activity of the reference catalyst (unsupported cobalt molybdenum nitride, Co3Mo3N) was tested. Initially, the catalysts that were pre-activated by ammonolysis, carried out in the external reactor, and then transferred to the catalytic reactor, were examined. The results are presented in a column of Table 4 ascribed as “After activation”. Next, the catalysts were subjected to the elevated temperature of 700 °C for 2 h to test their resistance to overheating. After that, the test of catalyti activity at 500 °C was repeated. These results are presented in the column of Table 4 ascribed as “After overheating”. After this procedure, the activity of the catalysts related to the Co/Mo mass was enhanced in relation to the unsupported Co3Mo3 N catalyst. For example, activity after overheating test, for CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 is equal to c.a. 340 μmolNH3·gcat −1·h−1, and for unsupported Co3Mo3N is equal to c.a. 620 μmolNH3·gcat −1·h−1. This means that for the catalyst with 10 times less content of cobalt and molybdenum, the activity was only two times lower. The catalytic test of the unsupported catalyst suggests a slight drop in activity after overheating. For the supported γ-alumina catalyst, we did not observe deactivation but rather activation of the catalyst. This result implies that, as observed during the quasi-in situ XPS study, the surface of the material is reconstructed and activated. The ammonia synthesis process for CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 catalyst was conducted in a long-term process, lasting 5 days at 500 °C. The content of the components in the reaction gas was measured continuously using a gas analyzer using Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). During the time-on-stream test, it was found that the concentration of ammonia in the post-reaction gas increased asymptotically, and then remained stable at about 800 ppm (Fig. 5 ). In agreement with the previous observations, the slow increase of the ammonia concentration suggests that the material needs a prolonged reactivation process in the reaction mixture (nitrogen + hydrogen) to reach the beneficial state of the surface. This is a result of activation of the oxidic surface of the catalyst as suggested by XPS and XANES analyses, despite the 2 h of initial ammonolysis pretreatment, which corresponds to mass stabilization as determined in TG measurement (Fig. S6). The stable concentration after the initial reactivation period proves the stability of the obtained catalyst in the temperature regime of the industrial process. The stability of the material was also proven by TG measurement. Reflections corresponding to the active phase have not been identified with XRD due to the small size and high dispersion of the particles. The TEM analysis, on the other hand, provides only the results on the local range. To obtain more information on the bulk of the material, the influence of reaction conditions on active phase dimensions was examined with the use of SAXS (Fig. S7). In both reference pure support γ-Al2O3 and CoMoN(9)/Al2O3 main population of nanoparticles is in the range of 1–10 nm, in comparison to Co3Mo3N where nanoparticles with diameters of 10–100 nm are mostly present (Fig. 6 ). The resilience of the nanoparticles to the sintering was examined. Most prominent differences are observed between populations of nanoparticles in the range of around 0.5–2 nm. In unsupported material this population disappears, most likely growing in size, while in supported material it remains stable. The goal of the presented study was to develop the method for the introduction of cobalt molybdenum species inside the porous structure of support and to develop the activation procedure, which results in the formation of cobalt molybdenum nitrides, active in the ammonia synthesis. The methods of synthesis of Co3Mo3N supported on alumina were already reported in the literature, however, this is mostly for catalysts tested with reactions other than ammonia synthesis [38,39]. Recently work regarding the synthesis of ammonia synthesis catalysts containing Co3Mo3N supported on silica was reported [46]. The presence of Co3Mo3N in the studied material was not confirmed directly, still, the comparison of the presented method to the known ones can be essential for the further development of the supported nitride systems. The method of preparation of Co3Mo3 N precursor deposited on alumina presented by Korlan et al. has 5 stages: the impregnation of a support with a solution of ammonium molybdate(VI), drying, impregnation with a solution of cobalt(II) nitrate(V), drying, calcination at 500 °C [38]. Then the obtained precursor is subjected to a nitriding process at 750 °C in pure ammonia, and followed by passivation. In comparison to the method of synthesis of supported cobalt molybdenum nitrides described by Korlan et al., the method presented in the present study is more convenient to use [38]. In particular, there is no need to conduct several impregnation and drying steps. In the case of the method reported by Logan et al., precursors were obtained by simultaneous impregnation of alumina with aqueous solutions of ammonium molybdate(VI) and cobalt(II) nitrate(V), followed by drying and calcining the obtained catalyst precursor [39]. After the activation at 700 °C in the ammonia flow, the active phase consisted of well-crystallized Co3Mo3 N easily detected by XRD analysis, which suggests agglomeration of particles, probably due to bulk deposition. Thus, the method presented in the present study is more suited to sustain developed porous structure and high dispersion of the active phase, contrary to the method described by Korlan et al. and Logan et al., in which a decrease in specific surface area from around 190 m2/g (reported in another work for pure Engelhard, AL-3945 Al2O3 support [62]) to 111 m2/g and from 255 to 175 m2/g, respectively. This is a result of the used impregnation under reduced pressure as well as a more suited for the available porous volume load of the active phase. The precursor introduction method reported by Sfeir et al. resulted in a significant decrease in accessible surface area from 760 m2/g to 295 m2/g for a 30 wt% load catalyst [46]. Furthermore, used silica is vulnerable to sintering at the ammonolysis conditions, which resulted in a decrease in both the pore volume and the surface area, from 1.12 cm3/g to 0.75 cm3/g and 760 m2/g to 504 m2/g, respectively. In the method presented in the present study is proven that the use of reduced pressure and relatively low loads allows for high dispersion of the active phase inside the porous support. In the activation step (the ammonolysis process) the oxidic precursor is transformed into active species. The porous structure of the support is unaffected by the ammonolysis, and only a small decrease in surface area and pore volume is observed. Furthermore, the presented method is relatively simple to perform, as it requires only one step for co-impregnation. Despite its simplicity, the presented synthesis method yields active and stable ammonia synthesis catalysts. 4 Conclusion A method for enhancing the textural and structural properties of Co-Mo catalyst, by increasing the homogeneity and dispersion of the active phase on the support surface was developed. All supported catalysts prepared were found to be active in the synthesis of ammonia, with all being resistant to overheating under the conditions used. Catalysts with an assumed total cobalt and molybdenum concentration of 3–9 wt% show greater activity related to the metal mass than the reference catalyst. The activity of supported catalysts was found to increase during overheating. The catalysts require a surface reactivation step after exposure to the air. Taking into account all the advantages of supported catalysts, like increased resistance to sintering, lower price compared to an unsupported catalyst, and over five times higher activity related to metals mass, such materials could be used for more efficient ammonia synthesis, especially nowadays, when energy becomes more expensive and limited. coredata.dc:description: Novel ammonia synthesis catalysts are sought due to energetic transformation and increasing environmental consciousness. Materials containing cobalt and molybdenum are showing state-of-art activities in ammonia synthesis. The application of γ-alumina support was proposed to enhance the properties of Co-Mo nanoparticles. The wet impregnation of the support was conducted under reduced pressure. The active catalysts were obtained by ammonolysis of precursors. The chemical and phase composition, as well as morphology, porosity, and surface composition of precursors and catalysts, were characterized. The Co-Mo nanoparticles phase composition as well as their size and dispersion were determined using X-ray absorption spectroscopy utilizing synchrotron radiation, electron microscopy, and X-ray scattering. The catalytic activity was tested in the ammonia synthesis process under atmospheric pressure. The activity and stability of the supported catalysts were compared with unsupported cobalt molybdenum nitride Co3Mo3N, revealing the superiority of the present approach.
